Warning: Long review coming up.
Up until January 2014, my only exposure to Irish Rail had been the odd trip from Cork to Cobh, where the commuter rail line is quite frankly the most direct option. Since January, I've gotten some experience with Irish Rail's long distance service, mostly on the Cork-Dublin Heuston line, which I've taken five times so far, plus an additional roundtrip on the Line from Dublin Connolly to Sligo.
Basically, Irish Rail's long distance services are served by two types of equipment. The Cork-Heuston line is mainly served by locomotive pulled trains consisting of what are known as Mk.IV coaches. These 8 car trains have both Second and first Class coaches, as well as a dedicated restaurant car. While they are older than the other long distance trains, they are still what I would consider the "flagship trains". Like all Irish Rail trains, there is free WiFi throughout the train, though the Mk. IV coaches do not have charge points for laptop chargers, etc. Please note that the Windows of the Mk. IV coaches have a distinctive blue tint which can make the outside appear cooler and darker than it really is.
All other long distance routes out of both Dublin Heuston and Dublin Connolly, with the exception of the cross border Enterprise service to Belfast, are served by InterCity Railcars. These are multiple units of between three and six cars, which can be coupled together. Not all Railcar units have a dedicated first class section or an onboard restaurant/bistro car. On these services, there will most likely be an onboard trolley service selling snacks & drinks. Free Wifi is available on these trains as well, and charge points are available throughout the train. The power packs for the ICR trains are underneath the floor of the trains, so you can expect the noise level in these trains to be higher than on the locomotive-hauled trains.
I've racked up quite a significant number of miles on trains in my life, from suburban services in the Greater London Area to the great high speed trains of France, Austria, and Germany. While Irish Rail is certainly no match for a TGV Duplex or an Austrian Railways Railjet, it does compare very favourably with regular long range trains on the continent. When it comes to cross-country travel within Ireland, they've become my option of choice whenever possible.
